docs.summary:
Adds or updates a localized content key for a given language.
Localized content is identified by its schemaKey and entityId.
Partial updates are supported - uploaded fields will be merged with existing language fields.
Override is also supported - need to mark explicitly in the request
Language content will be merged with entity's list of languages.

examples.title: createOrUpdateContentsByKey example for dashboard page code
createOrUpdateContentsByKey example for exporting from backend code

docs.summary: Retrieves localized content, including published and unpublished values, given the provided filtering.

examples.title: listContents example for dashboard page code
listContents example for exporting from backend code

docs.summary:
Removes specified content fields from given languages by contentId and sequencePath.
If no language is specified, the fields will be removed from all existing languages.
No error will be thrown if some fields do not exist in all languages.

examples.title: removeContentFields example for dashboard page code
removeContentFields example for exporting from backend code

docs.summary:
Removes specified content fields from given languages by schemaKey and entityId.
If no language is specified the fields will be removed from all existing languages.
Field is identified by its id and sequence path
No error will be thrown if some fields do not exist in all languages.

examples.title: removeContentFieldsByKey example for dashboard page code
removeContentFieldsByKey example for exporting from backend code

docs.summary: Removes existing localized content by contentId. Non-existent contentIds are ignored.

examples.title: removeContents example for dashboard page code
removeContents example for exporting from backend code

docs.summary: Removes existing localized content by contentKey. Non-existent contentKeys are ignored.

examples.title: removeContentsByKey example for dashboard page code
removeContentsByKey example for exporting from backend code
searchEntityContent example for dashboard page code
searchEntityContent example for exporting from backend code

docs.summary:
Updates existing localized content for a given language by contentId.
Partial updates are supported - uploaded fields will be merged with existing language fields.
Override is also supported - need to mark explicitly in the request
Language content will be merged with entity's list of languages.

examples.title: updateContents example for dashboard page code
updateContents example for exporting from backend code

members.name: appDefId
members.doc: An application definition id (app_id in dev-center). For legacy reasons may be UUID or a string (from Java Enum).

members.name: instanceId

members.doc: An application state.

members.name: _id
members.doc: This id must have a matching schema field id

members.name: sequencePath
members.doc: In case field is reachable via sequence/s, this array represents all the sequences names in the path, and their corresponding item id

members.doc: Content uuid identifier

members.name: _id
members.doc:
Unique event ID.
Allows clients to ignore duplicate webhooks.

members.name: entityEventSequence
members.doc:
A sequence number defining the order of updates to the underlying entity.
For example, given that some entity was updated at 16:00 and than again at 16:01,
it is guaranteed that the sequence number of the second update is strictly higher than the first.
As the consumer, you can use this value to ensure that you handle messages in the correct order.
To do so, you will need to persist this number on your end, and compare the sequence number from the
message against the one you have stored. Given that the stored number is higher, you should ignore the message.

members.name: entityFqdn
members.doc:
Assumes actions are also always typed to an entity_type
Example: wix.stores.catalog.product, wix.bookings.session, wix.payments.transaction

members.name: entityId
members.doc: ID of the entity associated with the event.

members.name: eventTime
members.doc: Event timestamp.

members.name: originatedFrom
members.doc: If present, indicates the action that triggered the event.

members.name: slug
members.doc:
This is top level to ease client code dispatching of messages (switch on entity_fqdn+slug)
This is although the created/updated/deleted notion is duplication of the oneof types
Example: created/updated/deleted/started/completed/email_opened

members.name: triggeredByAnonymizeRequest
members.doc:
Whether the event was triggered as a result of a privacy regulation application
(for example, GDPR).

members.name: deletedEntityAsJson
members.doc: Entity that was deleted

members.name: currentEntityAsJson
members.doc:
Since platformized APIs only expose PATCH and not PUT we can't assume that the fields sent from the client are the actual diff.
This means that to generate a list of changed fields (as opposed to sent fields) one needs to traverse both objects.
We don't want to impose this on all developers and so we leave this traversal to the notification recipients which need it.

members.name: originMetaSiteId
members.doc:
A meta site id from which this site was created.

In case of a creation from a template it's a template id.
In case of a site duplication ("Save As" in dashboard or duplicate in UM) it's an id of a source site.
